title: Received summons how do I respond? I have no monies and am disabled, cannot pay debt. Applying for Disability, unable to work.
question: This is a credit card debt that is less then 3300.00. I have written them several times telling them of my inability to pay any amount at this time because of my destitution. I have no means of support and will never be able to pay this debt. I am currently in the daunting application process of acquiring disability funds. I have NO MONIES. How do I respond to the summons, I have 30 days to complete the proper legal forms/writing to the powers that be, how do I do this? Help..........
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Credit,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Lawsuits and disputes,Fees,Default judgment
answers:
If you do not file an answer within thirty days, the creditor will go to court and get a default judgment. That means the judge will give them an order saying you owe the money and, most likely, their attorney fees and costs.

If you actually owe the debt, there may be little point in filing an answer because you would ultimately win the case, anyway. Sometimes it's easier to negotiate a settlement for a reduced amount, or a payment plan, if you act before a default judgment is filed, but you say you aren't in any position to pay even a reduced amount.

If they do get a judgment, collecting it from you is another matter. If you have no assets and wind up collecting disability, they probably can't take any portion of that from you... and even if they could. they can't leave you without enough to pay for the necessities of life.

A creditor has to sue you and get a judgment within certain time periods of they lose their right to collect forever. They probably just want the judgment so they can go after you if you win the lottery someday.

Please understand that this is a general discussion of legal principles by a California lawyer and does not create an attorney/client relationship. It's impossible to give detailed, accurate advice based on a few sentences on a website (and you shouldn't provide too much specific information about your legal matter on a public forum like Avvo, anyway). You should always seek advice from an attorney licensed in your jurisdiction who can give you an informed opinion after reviewing all of the relevant information.
